column4: Capital Calls: Tata Motors hits leadership pothole
column5: MUMBAI (Reuters Breakingviews) - Concise insights on global finance in the Covid-19 era.
column6: DRIVERLESS CARMAKER. Tata Motors is struggling to get a grip on the steering wheel. Ex-Daimler executive Marc Llistosella will no longer be joining the $15 billion owner of Jaguar Land Rover as chief executive of its Indian business in July due to “personal reasons”, the company revealed on Friday.
column7: Llistosella was to be the fifth boss in a decade – or sixth counting Cyrus Mistry who, following Karl Slym’s death in 2014, effectively assumed the role while also running the wider salt-to-hotels conglomerate. column8: The CEO potholes draw attention to Tata Motors’ lacklustre shareholder returns which for the past decade have trailed both Maruti and JLR rival BMW. After burning cash for two financial years, Tata Motors’ Indian business is finally getting back on track. It would be a bad time to leave the driver’s seat empty. (By Una Galani)

column4: Tata Motors says JLR aims to become net-zero carbon business by 2039
column5: Jaguar Land Rover’s luxury Jaguar brand will be entirely electric by 2025 and the carmaker will launch e-models of its entire lineup by 2030, it said on Monday, as it joined a global race to develop zero-emission vehicles.
column6: JLR, owned by India's Tata Motors (TAMO.NS), said its Land Rover brand will launch six pure electric models over the next five years, with the first one coming in 2024.
column7: Known for its iconic, high-performance E-Type model in the 1960s and 1970s, Jaguar faces the same challenge as many other carmakers - making the transition to electric vehicles while retaining the feeling and power of a luxury combustion engine model.
column8: JLR said it will keep all three of its British plants open as it electrifies its range. "It's time to re-imagine the next chapter for both brands," Chief Executive Thierry Bollore said.
column9: Shares in Tata Motors rose as much as 3% after the announcement.
column10: JLR said its electric plans for Jaguar would be centred at its Solihull plant, but dropped plans to build the XJ, the brand's flagship full-size car, at its Castle Bromwich facility in central England.
column11: Bollore, who took over as CEO in September, said the Castle Bromwich plant would focus instead on "non-production" activities in the long term. He provided few details.
column12: JLR said it will spend around 2.5 billion pounds ($3.5 billion) annually on electrification technologies and the development of connected vehicle services.
column13: The company said it was also investing in developing hydrogen fuel cells in anticipation of a future shift to hydrogen to power vehicles.
column14: The carmaker will have prototypes using hydrogen fuel cells on Britain's roads within the next year, it said, as part of a long-range investment plan.
column15: Car groups worldwide are pursuing zero-emission strategies to meet stringent CO2 emission targets in Europe and China.
column16: Luxury car brand Bentley Motors, owned by Germany’s Volkswagen (VOWG_p.DE), said in November its model range will be fully electric by 2030, and last month General Motors Co (GM.N) said it aimed to have a zero-emission lineup by 2035.
column17: A number of countries have also announced bans on new fossil-fuel vehicle sales. In the United Kingdom, that ban should take effect in 2030.
column18: JLR said it was a "on a path towards" a double-digit operating profit and positive cash flow, and aims to achieve positive cash excluding debt by 2025.

column4: Tata Motors worried by chip shortage, Brexit breakdowns
column5: BENGALURU (Reuters) - Jaguar Land Rover (JLR) owner Tata Motors is concerned by semiconductor shortages and Brexit-related supply disruptions as its luxury car sales recover, although the Indian automaker said on Friday these had not yet hit production.
column6: Tata Motors had three straight quarters of losses as the COVID-19 crisis dented sales, exacerbating uncertainties over Britain’s European Union exit, weak demand and rising costs, but has bounced back to clock a profit in its third quarter.
column7: “The issue is completely on the supply side rather than demand,” PB Balaji, chief financial officer, said after Tata Motors posted a 67.2% rise in profit for the last quarter of 2020, with improved sales at JLR in key markets like China.
column8: “Despite all this we aim to consolidate the gains we have had and finish the year strong,” Balaji said, adding that he expects sales in China to strengthen further.
column9: JLR sales in China jumped 20.2% quarter-on-quarter and were 19.1% higher on the same period a year before.
column10: Overall sales at the unit, which accounts for most of Tata Motors’ revenue, were up 13.1% from the previous quarter, but were still 9% lower than pre-pandemic levels.
column11: The Brexit trade deal agreed in December between Britain and its former EU partners, which avoided the risk of tariffs on automotive parts and finished vehicles, was largely in line with expectations, Balaji said.
column12: “In the immediate short term there is some degree of friction at the border because of paperwork that is coming through,” he said, adding that it is being managed without a material impact on production and should be resolved in weeks.
column13: Tata Motors said it saved 400 million pounds ($549 million) in the December quarter at JLR and is on track to achieve a full-year target of 2.5 billion pounds.
column14: The mid-November festive season, when Indians typically make big-ticket purchases, had also helped its domestic sales.

column4: Tata puts post-pandemic bet on digital, electronics and health
column5: (Reuters) - Tata Group plans to invest in digital, high-end electronics and healthcare in a post-pandemic world, the $100 billion conglomerate’s chairman said on Thursday.
column6: Tata, whose operations span hotels, steel, airlines, electronic goods and technology services, will also place big bets on electric vehicles, renewable energy and battery storage, N Chandrasekaran, who is also known as Chandra, added.
column7: “When you look at trends for the future, definitely there are clear signs you can pick up. Anything that is digital, we’re making a big bet on,” Chandra told the Reuters Next conference.
column8: The coronavirus pandemic has accelerated the adoption of technology, changing the way people live, work and consume as well as how companies operate, he added.
column9: Tata has already made public its intent to launch an umbrella app enabling access to all its consumer businesses, Chandra said, in a concept borrowed from China where apps such as Alipay allow everything from hotel bookings to e-commerce. Tata is also building an online business-to-business platform.
column10: The owner of British luxury brand Jaguar Land Rover (JLR) is placing big bets on electric vehicles as well as on battery storage and renewable energy for consumer and industrial use.
column11: “We are very serious about electric vehicles,” Chandra said, adding that Tata is investing in developing clean technology cars at home through Tata Motors and at JLR.
column12: Automakers are investing in EVs, largely driven by tighter government regulations on polluting vehicles, with Tesla, now the world’s most valuable car company, readying plans to launch in India this year.
column13: Chandra said the adoption of technology and shift in consumer and corporate behaviour will lead to the creation of new and shared workplaces closer to where people live.
column14: Meanwhile there will be a higher degree of automation in Indian factories driven by a greater use of artificial intelligence, internet of things or connected devices and data.
column15: With some of these changes unlikely to reverse, Chandra is looking at new opportunities for Tata, particularly as India’s economy springs back from damage during the early stages of the pandemic last year.
column16: “I’ve been quite surprised with the speed with which the economy is recovering and bouncing back,” he said, adding that several Tata companies are already recovering losses as demand picks up except in areas like airlines.
column17: COVID-19 has also forced Tata to be more resilient to disruption in the global supply chains it depends on and for Chandra, one way to do this is to be a part of it.
column18: “There are couple of industries we have already identified. One is electronics, high-tech manufacturing, where we’ve already started the foray and we are developing plans for the future.”
column19: Tata also plans to cater to growing demand for medical devices in India and around the world, Chandra said.

column4: No UK port problems so far for Jaguar Land Rover
column5: (Reuters) - Luxury carmaker Jaguar Land Rover has not seen any impact so far from issues at UK ports, its parent Tata Motors said on Thursday, even as many countries cut transport ties with Britain due to a fast-spreading new variant of the coronavirus.
column6: Tokyo-listed Honda Motor Co Ltd had to stop output at its British factory earlier this month because of transport-related delays that caused a shortage of parts. It resumed production about a week later.
column7: The COVID-19 pandemic has compounded issues that were already plaguing carmakers ahead of Brexit, with the looming end to the transition period widely expected to cause delays at ports regardless of the outcome of talks on a trade deal.
column8: Jaguar Land Rover halted production at its British factories for a week in November last year to mitigate any potential impact from a no-deal Brexit ahead of the then Oct. 31 deadline.

column4: U.S. opens probe into whether VW vehicles infringe Jaguar Land Rover patents
column5: WASHINGTON (Reuters) -The U.S. International Trade Commission (ITC) said on Monday it is opening in investigation into whether German automaker Volkswagen AG infringed on patents held by Jaguar Land Rover for a system used for off-road driving.
column6: In November, Jaguar Land Rover, a unit of Tata Motors, filed a complaint with the ITC seeking to prevent the import of some VW Porsche, Lamborghini and Audi models with “certain vehicle control systems” that allegedly infringe on its patents.
column7: The models include the Lamborghini Urus, Porsche Cayenne and Audi’s Q8, Q7, Q5, A6 Allroad, and e-tron vehicles and the VW Tiguan. The ITC said it has made no decision on the merits.
column8: VW said in a statement it was examining the action and determining its next steps.
column9: “We will of course cooperate with investigating authorities. While we cannot comment on any details of the proceedings, we strongly believe that the claims have no merit and will robustly defend our position,” VW said.
column10: Jaguar Land Rover (JLR) said the vehicles “have used JLR’s patented inventions without payment or permission” notably a patent for an “improved system for driving a vehicle on different driving surfaces, in particular off-road.”
column11: JLR says its Terrain Response technology uses the patented technology to maximize performance on off-road driving surfaces, including grass, snow, mud, sand and rocks.

column4: Tata Motors sees better second half even as it prepares for hard Brexit
column5: BENGALURU (Reuters) - India’s Tata Motors Ltd forecast a stronger second half on Tuesday as sales of its Jaguar Land Rover (JLR) vehicles improved in key markets even as it continued to grapple with the COVID-19 pandemic and uncertainties over a hard Brexit.
column6: The global health crisis has hammered sales for automakers worldwide and compounded problems for the company’s luxury unit, which, like most companies, will have to face a wall of bureaucracy as Britain casts off from the European Union from Jan. 1.
column7: Tata Motors said while it was prepared for any friction at the border, it hoped for clarity on Brexit to avoid supply chain disruptions and better manage its inventory.
column8: “In the situation of a hard Brexit, we expect to see tariffs definitely come through but we also expect depreciation of the pound, and so the net impact needs to be seen,” Chief Financial Officer PB Balaji told reporters after Tata Motors posted a quarterly loss.
column9: While the automaker may need to correct its inventory level to an extent, it does not have any immediate plans to move production, Balaji said.
column10: Tata Motors posted a consolidated net loss of 3.14 billion rupees ($42.47 million) for the second quarter ended Sept. 30, as retail sales at JLR, which accounts for a major portion of its profit, fell 12%.
column11: Total revenue from operations fell 18% to 535.3 billion rupees, the carmaker said in a filing with the exchange.
column12: The company said it had saved 600 million pounds ($782 million) during the quarter at JLR under Project Charge and was on track to achieve the full-year target of 2.5 billion pounds.

column4: Indian shares close at over seven-month high on Tata Motors, HDFC boost
column5: BENGALURU (Reuters) - Indian shares closed at more than a seven-month high on Tuesday, helped by gains in Tata Motors and HDFC Ltd, with investors shifting focus to the outcome of the central bank’s two-day policy meeting scheduled later in the week.
column6: The Nifty ended 1.38% up at 11,662.4, its highest close since Feb. 26, while the Sensex gained 1.54% to close at 39,574.57.
column7: “We’re now eyeing the 11,800 zone (for Nifty), so traders should continue with ‘buy on dips’ in the index while stocks may continue to see the swings on both sides,” said Ajit Mishra, vice president of research at Religare Broking.
column8: Housing finance company HDFC Ltd added 8.4% and was the top gainer on the Nifty, saying loan disbursements during the September quarter were at 95% of the level from a year earlier.
column9: Carmaker Tata Motors rose 8.1% after sales at its luxury Jaguar Land Rover unit rose more than 50% sequentially for the September quarter.
column10: The Reserve Bank of India said on Tuesday it would hold its two-day monetary policy committee meeting from Oct. 7 to Oct. 9, having delayed it by a week. The central bank is widely expected to keep rates steady. (reut.rs/2I2Jcbt)
column11: Late on Monday, the government named three nominees to the central bank’s monetary policy committee.

column4: Tata Motors says it will significantly reduce $6.4 bln debt over 3 years
column5: NEW DELHI, Aug 25 (Reuters) - India’s Tata Motors Ltd will significantly reduce its group automotive debt of 480 billion rupees ($6.4 billion) over the next three years, the company’s chairman said during its annual shareholder meeting on Tuesday.
column6: Tata Motors is “deleveraging this business substantially” and has set targets to generate free cash flows, N Chandrasekaran said.
column7: Automakers globally have been hit by the COVID-19 pandemic which has hurt demand for cars and disrupted supply chains because of curbs on travel and the movement of goods.
column8: This has derailed Tata Motors’ turnaround plans for its domestic business and British luxury unit, Jaguar Land Rover (JLR), but the company said it is committed to cutting costs, tightening investment spending and improving profitability.
column9: “The company is working with agility to transform towards a future that is strong, sustainable, and financially rewarding,” Chandrasekaran said, adding that the group would also look to “unlock non-core investments”.
column10: Tata Motors’ domestic business is expected to generate free cash flows from fiscal year 2021 while JLR will achieve this a year later in 2022, the company’s CFO, P B Balaji said during the virtual shareholder meeting.
column11: Shares of Tata Motors ended 5% higher on Tuesday while the broader Mumbai market remained flat. (Reporting by Aditi Shah, additional reporting by Derek Francis in Bengaluru; Editing by Nick Tattersall)

column4: Tata warns of another loss at JLR as demand slow to pick up
column5: NEW DELHI/BENGALURU (Reuters) - India's Tata Motors Ltd TAMO.NS warned on Friday that its luxury car unit, Jaguar Land Rover (JLR), may post another quarterly loss as the coronavirus crisis saps demand and cripples its supply chain.
column6: The pandemic has taken a heavy toll on automakers globally and piled pressure on Tata Motors, which has been trying to improve JLR’s cash flows by reining in costs after geopolitical and regulatory challenges hurt the British carmaker’s sales.
column7: Tata Motors raised its cost savings target for JLR by 1 billion pounds ($1.31 billion) and now expects to save 6 billion pounds in costs by March 2021, Chief Financial Officer PB Balaji said on Friday, noting that it had already achieved savings of 4.7 billion pounds.
column8: “As much as we take on costs and reduce cash burn, demand is a very important lever for this business,” Balaji said, adding that even though sales were improving demand was not coming back in a hurry.
column9: Unit sales at JLR, which accounts for most of the company’s revenue, fell over 42% during the quarter, while its EBITDA (earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization) margin was 3.5%.
column10: Earlier this week, JLR named ousted Renault boss Thierry Bollore as its next chief executive, with a mission to return the carmaker to profit.
column11: Balaji said while JLR’s electrification plans are on track, the company may drop or go back to the drawing board on certain projects that are not “great on financial returns”. He did not specify which projects were being re-looked at.
column12: Tata Motors reported bit.ly/319kXxY consolidated net loss of 84.38 billion rupees ($1.13 billion) for its first quarter, compared with a loss of 36.98 billion rupees a year earlier.
column13: The company said it expects a gradual pickup in demand and an improvement in supply in the second half of fiscal 2020-2021.

column7: It will also reduce capital expenditure at JLR to 2.5 billion pounds for the current fiscal year, from the more than 3 billion pounds it has spent annually in previous years.
column8: “Conserving cash and prioritising capital expenditure, and targeting investment spending to the right areas is our focus,” Balaji told reporters, after the company posted a fourth quarter loss.
column9: We anticipate that up to 1,100 agency employees will be affected, a JLR spokeswoman said in a separate statement.
column10: Tata Motors is reviewing all its businesses and would consider exiting those that do not add strategic value, as part of a broader effort to save 60 billion rupees ($789 million) in its domestic business in the fiscal year to 2021.
column11: The automaker on Monday posted a consolidated fourth quarter net loss of 98.94 billion rupees, as coronavirus lockdowns across its markets ravaged sales, including at JLR.
column12: Total revenue from operations fell 27.7% to 624.93 billion rupees in the quarter, which ended March 31.
column13: JLR, which contributes the bulk of Tata Motors’ revenues, reported a pre-tax loss of 501 million pounds for the period after it took a hit of 800 million pounds because of the novel coronavirus, Balaji said.

column4: India's Tata Motors to spin off car division as separate unit

column7: Car sales in India have dropped for 16 straight months up to February amid slowing economic growth, while the pandemic has halted auto production as the government imposed a 21-day nationwide lockdown this week.
column8: Tata, the owner of British luxury car brands Jaguar and Land Rover, said in a statement the move would allow it to sharpen focus separately on its two businesses: passenger and commercial vehicles.

column4: Tata Motors, two group finance firms accused of antitrust violations in India: sources
column5: NEW DELHI (Reuters) - India’s competition regulator is examining allegations that Tata Motors and two finance firms of its $100 billion parent group abused their market position while selling commercial vehicles, according to three sources and legal documents seen by Reuters.
column6: The Competition Commission of India (CCI) is reviewing a complaint which alleges the country’s biggest seller of trucks dictated terms around the quantity and type of vehicles its former dealer in northern India - Varanasi Auto Sales - should stock.
column7: More than a dozen lawyers representing the three Tata companies attended a private hearing at the CCI in January and argued there was no malpractice by the group’s firms, said the three sources, who have direct knowledge of the matter.
column8: The Tata Group has faced antitrust reviews in the past. A CCI investigation last year found units of Tata Steel TISC.NS and other firms colluded on prices of bearings. A final ruling on that case is pending.
column9: The latest complaint, filed last year by a family member of the dealer, alleged Tata Motors TAMO.NS broke rules by working in concert with Tata Motors Finance and Tata Capital Financial Services while advancing dealer credit.
column10: The automaker would stop supplying vehicles to the dealer if repayment of loans advanced by the two finance firms was delayed, indicating they were colluding, said one of the sources privy to the complaint.
column11: “(The) model of business adopted by Tata Group helped in sustaining and retaining the market share,” the complaint document said.
column12: In response to Reuters queries, Tata Motors said it had made submissions to the CCI and would provide full support to the watchdog. It added the CCI was “conducting a preliminary enquiry to determine if there are any merits to the case”.
column13: Tata Capital Financial Services denied the allegations and said it would also support inquiries, adding it had separately taken legal action against the dealer, which it said had defaulted.
column14: Tata Motors ended relations with the dealership in 2017 due to poor performance, the documents showed.
column15: The CCI did not respond to Reuters queries, but a fourth source aware of the case said the watchdog would reach a decision within six weeks, which could see a wider probe into the allegations or a dismissal of the complaint.
column16: The details of the complaint and the ongoing proceedings are not public.
column17: The CCI has powers to impose a penalty of up to 10% of the relevant turnover of a company in the last three financial years if it is found to have abused a dominant position.
column18: With an over 40% market share in India, Tata Motors is the biggest seller of commercial vehicles such as pickup trucks. It competes with firms such as Ashok Leyland ASOK.NS and Mahindra and Mahindra MAHM.NS and has over 3,750 sales and service points across India.

column5: MUMBAI (Reuters Breakingviews) - Zero-emission cars will be a road test of conglomerate power. Tata is drawing on expertise from across its $160 billion empire to support an electric vehicle initiative. Patriarch Ratan Tata attended Tuesday’s unveiling of the Nexon EV in Mumbai along with bosses of more than a half-dozen related companies. If the plan works, it could deliver rare and valuable synergies.
column6: The bold strategy signals a strong commitment to turn Tata Motors into a force in green cars. The Indian government, keen to reduce pollution and high oil import bills, wants 30% of new passenger vehicles sold to be electric by 2030, up from less than 1% of the 3.4 million sold in the year to March. But they are already popular for fleet customers and volumes will rise as battery costs fall and more models become available. China’s Great Wall Motors, for example, is widely expected to roll out a super-cheap model in India next month.
column7: Tata Motors will have been able to move faster, thanks to its ownership of Jaguar Land Rover. The boss of those luxury brands, Ralf Speth, will retire in September, the carmaker announced Thursday, after a difficult decade in the job. column8: The Indian group is tapping many other parts of the realm, too. Tata Power, for example, will have 650 charging stations across the country over the next year. Owners of Tata-branded cars will have priority access and tariffs. column9: The Indian group is tapping many parts of the realm, allowing it to move faster. It’ll be a corporate triumph to get the project humming on all cylinders.

column4: Tata Motors reveals turnaround plan for Jaguar Land Rover after loss
column5: MUMBAI/BENGALURU (Reuters) - India's Tata Motors Ltd TAMO.NS on Wednesday announced a turnaround plan for its luxury car unit Jaguar Land Rover which has been hit hard by trade tensions between China and the US, low demand for diesel cars in Europe and worries over Brexit.
column6: Under “Project Charge” Tata Motors said it plans to cut costs and improve cash flows at Jaguar Land Rover (JLR) by 2.5 billion pounds ($3.2 billion) over 18 months.
column7: JLR also plans to launch several new vehicles including the Jaguar I-Pace and the new Range Rover Defender over the next few years and will offer a hybrid or electric version of all its models by 2020.
column8: “Together with our ongoing product offensive and calibrated investment plans, these efforts will lay the foundations for long-term sustainable growth,” JLR CEO Ralf Speth said after Tata Motors reported a loss for the second-quarter.
column9: JLR has trimmed its pre-tax profit expectations for the current fiscal year ending March 31, 2019 and expects to break even, Speth said, versus an earlier target of profit growth.
column10: As part of the turnaround plan, JLR will first focus on cash saving “quick wins” like reducing non-product investments and speeding up asset sales, Tata Motors said in an investor presentation.
column11: In the near term it will improve efficiency in areas including purchasing and material cost, manufacturing and logistics and people and will focus on strategic and non-core asset sales. JLR has already reduced the number of production days at its UK plants in Castle Bromwich and Solihull.
column12: The company said in its presentation it has saved 300 million pounds since it initiated the turnaround plan six weeks ago and is working on 500 ideas for the future.
column13: Tata Motors made a loss of 10.49 billion rupees ($141.9 million) for the July-September quarter, compared with a profit of 24.83 billion rupees in the year-ago period. That was worse than the estimate of a loss of 2.40 billion rupees, according to Refinitiv data.
column14: JLR reported a loss of 101 million pounds during the quarter and its margin on earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization (EBITDA) fell 130 basis points to 9.9 percent.
column15: Retail sales of its Jaguar saloons and Land Rover sport utility vehicles (SUVs) fell 13.2 percent to about 130,000 units, hurt particularly by tariff changes in China and escalating trade tensions.
column16: Demand in China remained muted even after the country cut import tariffs for cars and car parts to 15 percent for most vehicles from 25 percent from July.
column17: Tata Motors’ domestic business reported a profit of 1.09 billion rupees and EBITDA margin rose 210 basis points to 8.7 percent during the quarter from a year ago. The automaker incurred a one-off charge of 4.37 billion rupees due to the closure of operations at its Thailand-based subsidiary.

column4: India wrestlers get sponsor boost ahead of Asian Games
column5: MUMBAI (Reuters) - India’s wrestlers received a welcome boost ahead of this month’s Asian Games after the federation got automaker Tata Motors as their principal sponsor on Wednesday.
column6: Wrestling has been the most productive sport in recent times at the Olympics for the country, bringing in five medals - one silver and four bronze - in the last three Games.
column7: While some wrestlers have received sponsorship in individual capacities, the Wrestling Federation of India had been looking for corporate support for its athletes’ international training and exposure trips.
column8: Tata Motors, owner of British luxury brands Jaguar and Land Rover, will sponsor wrestling for three years, beginning with the upcoming Asian Games in Jakarta and will continue till 2021.
column9: “I am happy with the adulation the sport has received ever since 2008 Beijing Olympics as we have been successfully winning medals in three consecutive Olympics,” Sakshi Malik, who won a bronze at the Rio Olympics, told reporters.

column4: Tata Motors skids to first quarterly loss in three years
column5: NEW DELHI/BENGALURU (Reuters) - India's Tata Motors Ltd TAMO.NS reported its first quarterly loss in nearly three years on Tuesday as its British unit Jaguar Land Rover (JLR) sold fewer of its luxury cars to dealerships in China and expenses rose.
column6: Dealers in China delayed purchases to benefit from an import duty cut that came into effect after the end of the quarter, the automaker said.
column7: China decided to cut import tariffs for cars and car parts to 15 percent for most vehicles from 25 percent starting July 1, opening up greater access to the world’s largest auto market and helping to ease a recent flare-up in trade tensions with the United States. The move should in coming quarters provide a boost for overseas carmakers.
column8: “We expect sales and financial results to improve over the remainder of the financial year ... with the new lower duties effective in China,” JLR CEO Ralf Speth said in Tata’s results statement.
column9: Tata Motors’ Chief Financial Officer PB Balaji said headwinds facing JLR included its China sales levels as well as worries over Britain’s departure from the European Union and the diesel policy in Europe.
column10: “China is probably the biggest one. We need to ensure China gets back to the growth rate that it was before the announcement of duty cuts,” Balaji told reporters.
column11: In terms of Brexit, he said the company was preparing for worst-case scenarios, without elaborating, and was “gearing up for any eventuality that may be there.”
column12: His comments came as the head of Britain’s car industry warned on Tuesday that if Britain were to leave the EU without a trade deal with the bloc that would raise costs and sow chaos for carmakers and consumers alike.
column13: “Given these issues, we will remain focused on driving growth and simultaneously reducing costs and boosting
column14: operational efficiency and capability,” JLR’s Speth said.
column15: Tata Motors reported a net loss of 19.02 billion rupees ($277 million) for its first quarter ended June 30, compared with a profit of 31.82 billion rupees a year earlier that included a 36.09 billion rupee gain from changes to the way JLR’s pension payments are calculated.
column16: Even as JLR’s retail sales for the quarter rose 6 percent to 145,510 units helped by strong sales of its sport-utility vehicles - the Range Rover Velar and Jaguar E-Pace - quarterly revenue fell 6.7 percent because of lower wholesale orders.
column17: The company reiterated its target of achieving between 4 percent and 7 percent growth in margins at JLR for the current fiscal year 2018-19.
column18: Total expenses during the April-June quarter rose about 17 percent to 698.90 billion rupees.
column19: To rein in costs, Tata Motors will restructure its business in Thailand. It plans to stop manufacturing vehicles in Thailand and will instead set up a distribution network to sell imported vehicles, Balaji said.
column20: Tata Motors reported a quarterly profit of 11.88 billion rupees in its business in India excluding JLR, reversing a loss in the same period a year earlier and helped by higher sales of its passenger and commercial vehicles.
